string.text: The rules of the tournament are standard across Japan. We match the fighters up by drawing lots. Sometimes you're part of a team, and sometimes you fight by yourself.

As well you might! They're a grand old custom that's now spread all over Japan. Back in the old days, they'd give a hundred condemned criminals swords and have them slash at each other until the sands were drenched in blood![if:convo_merry]
The rules of the tournament are standard across Japan. We match the fighters up by drawing lots. Sometimes you're part of a team, and sometimes you fight by yourself.
'For all the coin aboard the Black Ships \n For all the tribute of the Great Ming \n For all the jade of Yunnan’s hills...'

Ah, no. Slavers are rare these days. It used to be that, when the clans made war upon each other, the defeated were usually taken as slaves. That helped pay for the war, you see! But today, for better or for worse, that is not practical. With the scale of wars Japan has found itself in, there are far too many opportunities for captives to escape. But that does not mean that war cannot be profitable! Indeed it still can!
Many captives are still taken, and their families will pay to have them back. Men such as I criss-cross Japan, acquiring prisoners, and contacting their kin for a suitable ransom.

Oh, I suppose I could sell them to the pirates of Ryukyu, to row their bunes, although even in Ryukyu they prefer free oarsmen these days... But it rarely comes to that. You'd be surprised what sorts of treasures a peasant can dig out of his cowshed or wheedle out of his cousins!

It varies. I fancy that I have a fine eye for assessing a ransom. There are a dozen little things about a man that will tell you whether he goes to bed hungry, or spices his meat with pepper and cloves. The real money of course is in the aristocracy, and if you ever want to do my job you'll want to learn about every landowning family or tribal chief in Japan, their estates, their offspring both lawful and bastard, and, of course, their credit with the merchants.
Of course. I'm welcome in every court in Japan. There's not many who can say that! So always be sure to keep a pot of mon buried somewhere, and a loyal servant who can find it in a hurry.
Monkey sings up in the pine. 'I stole the daimyo’s favorite wine.'{newline}Crow replies with feathered grin, 'That lord of Kai is drunk again.'
Miyoshi rule Osaka fair. But daggers flash within the lair.{newline}One by one their lights go out. And whispers take the halls with doubt.
Nobunaga always schemes. Talks of guns and foreign dreams.{newline}Builds a castle in a day, then burns ten temples on the way.
Ieyasu sits, both calm and still. Waiting as the rice fields fill.{newline}Speaks but once, and none deny. A turtle's patience wins the sky.
Chosokabe grows his rice. And counts his sons like clans of mice.{newline}The island sleeps, but not for long. He teaches peasants to be strong.
The priest of Enryaku rang his bell. To scare off demons back to hell.{newline}But the demon laughed and stayed the night. Said ‘Your prayer was weak, now pass the rice.’
Saburo Saburo fought a boar. Drove it screaming to the floor.{newline}Not with blade or sharpened spear. But garlic breath and gourd of beer.
Growing up in the city, you spent most of your time...
Like all village children you worked from a young age. You spend your time...
As a youngster growing up in Japan, war was never too far away. You...

You spent your adolescence days training your sword skills together with other kids. Whether it was with real blades or improvised ones, in actual practice or imaginary duels, you improved your slashes and parries with no need to roll around.

You were sent to study with a scholar to deepen your mathematical knowledge and learn the basics of physics. Day after day, you learned the secrets of calculation and engineering, giving you the skills to draw your first projects and draft detailed records.

You accompanied a merchant as his apprentice, learning his trade and acquiring the skills of a good salesman. After an adolescence spent between markets and warehouses, you learnt the secrets of bargaining and commerce.

You spent your adolescence working in a forge as the apprentice of a master swordsmith, learning the secrets of forge and blade in equal measure. By the end of your apprenticeship, you were able to forge a sword discreetly on your own, and why not, even swing it around.

You were sent to work as a young servant at the estate of a rich landowner from the city. Gradually progressing from menial tasks to more complex ones, you eventually became a sort of administrator of the estate, managing its stocks and liaising with the guests of your master. Once your service with the wealthy landlord was over, you were a young adult able to administer a fortune and deal with the city's high society.

You spent your adolescence on the streets of the city, often getting into trouble and growing closer and closer to the local underworld, eventually becoming a member of a gang of young criminals. After years in this environment, you have learned all the secrets of commiting crimes and getting out of the resulting trouble.

As a kid you went almost every day to train with a jizamurai who stayed in your village for a few years and who seemed to like you enough to teach you how to fight for free. When your mentor finally left the village by the time you had become a young adult, you were a discreet and robust fighter.

You spent your adolescence working in a forge as the apprentice of a blacksmith, being educated in the production of tools for the fields and the other activities in the village. By the end of your apprenticeship, you had become yourself a skilled blacksmith capable of crafting and handling several tools

Your father was the trusted retainer of a jito, a minor lord in charge of a manor or estate. After several years of loyal service as bodyguard and enforcer, he was raised to the rank of samurai and with that he was granted the right to carry a sword and was provided with a mount and armour to accompany his master.

Your family thrived in the trade of sake. From their house in one of the largest towns of Japan they ran several breweries and sold their products to customers throughout the Country. Despite the wealth they accumulated over the years and the influence that it carried, their less than friendly practices with their competitors stained their reputation with mistrust and contempt from most.

Your father was a humble but skilled swordsmith who through his physical strength and mastery of his art was able to transform raw metal into sharp blades, making him well known in his domain for the quality of his creations. Even as a child, by helping him in the forge, you were able to absorb some of his craftmanship and harden your body.

A disgraced samurai who had lost his master, your father wandered the countryside as a ronin in search of opportunities and trouble. Being unable to avenge his fallen master and recover his previous standing, he was forced to accept employment as a mercenary or cutthroat to survive. Despite originally hailing from a higher class, your father's demotion and turbulent history are still a shame to wash away from your family.

A soldier for hire, your father travelled around the country looking for a new employer, hoping his next job would pay enough and not cost him his life. Only after many bloody battles and scarred wounds he retired, the money he had saved being enough to allow him to settle down in the countryside for a simple but comfortable life.

Your father was the head of a flourishing tea farm, cultivating the delicate leaves with expertise and dedication the ancient traditions. While as head of the farm your father was entitled to a large share of the profits, he was still a farmer and never shied away from manual labour, and you too, spending your childhood among the tea bushes, grew very familiar with farm tools and herbs.

Living on the outskirts of his village, your father was a skilled hunter, well-versed in tracking and chasing his prey through the woods and mountains. and taking it down with a swift stroke of his bow. Even if the rewards of his labour were barely enough for a humble life in the countryside, your father passed on much of his knowledge to you.

Your parents were members of a renowned company of Noh actors. Together with their companions they travelled around the country enchanting audiences with their timeless performances and trying to make a living out of it. In spite of the obvious impossibility of settling down, your parents' profession was the source of a deep knowledge of the different peoples of Japan and the skills needed to socialise with them.
as a servant to a wealthy family.

In your adolescence you were sent to a workshop as the apprentice of the local carpenter, learning the different ways of working wood and stone and how to use them for the construction of buildings essential to village life. To conclude your apprenticeship you lead the construction of the new village warehouse, proving your grasp of the fields of mathematics and engineering.

You spent the days of your adolescence working in the fields of a farm, in a job that was far from exciting but nevertheless necessary. The years spent working the land under the sun or transporting the harvest made you much stronger and more accustomed to handling farm tools.

As a kid you loved going into the woods and mountains with the hunters from the village, observing them and learning their skills. After several years benefiting from their guidance and teaching, you eventually became an integral part of the group as a skilled hunter yourself.
as a young actor in a noh troop.

As a teenager you chose to leave and join a company of noh actors, travelling and performing with them from town to town. After years of convincing representations and observing people's reactions, you have become not just a skilled actor, but also someone who can convince and deceive others with only your words.
raised by monks in a temple.

Whether out of necessity or simple orphanhood, as a child you were placed in the care of a Buddhist monastery. The monks who raised you did not only instruct you in religious matters, but also in calligraphy, rhetoric, the knowledge of nature and the ways to use it to heal the body.

Thanks to your wealth or your social standing, you were able to join the army not as an ordinary soldier but as its commander's sandal-bearer, a sort of aide-de-camp and protégé. From the command tent or on the battlefield, you benefited from the mentoring of an experienced commander, learning first-hand what it means to lead soldiers in war.
Joined a gang of criminals in the city.
Sometimes to avoid being oppressed, it is better to join the oppressors. You joined a local gang, finding your safety in the strength of the pack while you learnt the ropes of the urban underworld.
Joined an army as a horseman.

When you enlisted the cavalry commander had you join his ranks, your riding skills had caught his attention and the fact your wealth allowed you to buy your own horse only strengthened his choice. Equipped as a light horseman, you often took part in scouting and skirmishing missions.
Became a messenger for a local army.

Your talent for memorization and sufficient riding skills caught the attention of the commander of your army, who entrusted you with the task of delivering his messages, partly written and partly memorised. Equipped with a fast horse and light armour, you rode through several battlefields often influencing the outcome with the information you transformed.
Fell in with a group of bandits.

To survive in the war-torn countryside, you chose to join a group of bandits to make a living at the expense of the very people who lived in the countryside. Killing and looting together with your gang, not too dissimilar from the plundering of passing armies, you became a ruthless raider.

If peace cannot be found on land, the seas are not entirely safe either. To escape the power struggles of the samurai, you chose to join a group of wokou pirates, attacking merchant ships careless enough to pass through pirate-controlled routes. Although it is easier to fight merchants than a samurai, ships are often defended by armed guards and you had your fair share of combat experience in addition to sailing.
Offered your service as an ashigaru spearman.

Large formations of ashigaru spearmen are the backbone of every army in warring Japan, but also its most expendable and easily accessible part. As a rank-and-file soldier you gained your combat experience alongside your comrades learning to defend yourself with the yari spear you were issued.
Helped build fortifications around the camp.

Not every member of an army is expected to fight in battle, logistics being a vital necessity for any military campaign and those who take care of them as important as fighters. Joining the rearguard, you assisted with setting up camp and building fortifications.
Joined an army as an archer.

As you enlisted in an army, you were noticed for your archery skills and were assigned to the ranks of bowmen supporting the soldiers engaged in melee combat from afar. Through constant training and battle experience, you became a dependable member of the unit, providing vital support with your yumi bow and arrows.

As the newest member of the army you had joined, you were sent forward with almost minimal if any equipment to scout the terrain ahead of the marching troops. As an increasingly skillful and experienced scout, you ventured into unknown territories, mapping enemy positions and gathering crucial intelligence that frequently proved decisive for the success of your army's strategies.
Joined a temple as a monk

You managed to avoid war in your youth by joining a temple. Temples are not only a spiritual place, but an educative one. As a monk you spent many nights studying philosophy, poetry, law, war, and more. Your studies have granted you a unique insight into the art of war and administration.

You were part of the garrison of a castle-town that was besieged by an enemy army. As one of the many defenders you were called to secure the defensive positions until the enemies were finally repulsed and lifted the siege.
You do not have enough ships to carry all your troops.

The Fall of the Triple Alliance

Oda Nobunaga has successfully marched on Kyoto and installed Ashikaga Yoshiaki as the new Shogun of Japan. Although this was done with the intention of strengthening the Ashikaga Shogunate, Yoshiaki will soon realize he is another puppet shogun like Yoshihide before him. For now, the central authority of the Shogun remains weak.
The Honjo rebellion has been crushed by the Uesugi. All rebel clans have been forced to recognize the authority of the Uesugi clan, and have been brought back into the fold.
The Kimotsuki rebellion has been crushed by the Shimazu. The Kimotsuki have been forced to swear loyalty to the Shimazu, ending their bid for independence.

The fragile triple alliance between the Takeda, Hojo, and Imagawa clans has finally collapsed. The Takeda have invaded the Suruga Province of the Imagawa with the help of the Tokugawa, but the Uesugi has agreed to come to their aid. Now the Takeda face a two front war with minimal allies, which will decide the fate of the Chubu region.

Ashikaga Yoshiaki, with the aid of Oda Nobunaga, has declared themselves the rightful Shogun of Japan. The armies of the Oda clan march on Kyoto. If they manage to wipe out any resistance in their way, Yoshiaki will become the new Shogun of Japan.
The Honjo rebellion has managed to defeat the Uesugi, and carve for themselves a new kingdom. The Uesugi are forced to accept their independence.
The Kimotsuki rebellion has managed to defeat the Shimazu, and carve for themselves a new kingdom. The Shimazu are forced to accept their independence.
5% of the village income is paid to the ruler clan as tax{newline}5% less village income for clans
Conduct surveys to evaluate taxes for farms and fields by considering not only their size but also the quality of their harvests.

Choosing a single merchant to lead over the rest of the domain's merchants means they will have supervision over market peddlers, authority to collect taxes from merchants, and sole control over market affairs. This brings in more income through taxes at the cost of certain maketplace freedoms.
allowing the ruler to appoint magistrates

Assigning magistrates, called Daikan, to solve disputes and render verdicts on crimes will help cut down on gang activity and lawlessness. Unfortunately, this is often greatly resented by affected communities.
Currency shortages can be allieviated by allowing imported coins and wartime minted coins to have monetary value. The people will likely be reluctant to accept these new currencies.
Ships entering ports or harbors must pay taxes according to their size, amount, and type of cargo they are carrying.
Establish an economic policy that denies certain merchants privileges in towns and ports, but gives certain guarantees and tax exemptions for businesses.
In response to the need for a stronger and more organized military, lesser lords could be added to the ranks of armies in the field to bolster their concentration of power.
Talented warriors excelling in martial arts are recruited into the umamawari, an organized escort for the ruler.
Wartime taxes, called yasen, can be collected from temples, shrines, and merchants. Doing so will increase tax gain at the cost of town prosperity and more influence needed to declare war.

The ruler may consider the opinions of those lower in the hierarchy to suppress discontent but the final decision will remain the ruler's alone. Establishing this will allow the ruler greater authority when overriding certain decisions.
Samurai clans can be incorporated into the imperial court hierarchy, further separating the power between the ranks of each clan.
Samurai who make strides on the battlefield can be rewarded for their service. These can include fiefdoms and certificates of gratitude, bringing honor to their clan and families.
Issuance of Certificates and Distribution of Territories
Domains can specify strict and formal laws of inheritance making it more difficult to revoke land.

By fleeing villages, peasants can escape the path of war at the risk of leaving the area abandoned. Doing so can cause hardships for those left behind and those of neighboring regions, who must now do the work of those who fled. Peasants can be ordered to return, with exemptions of burden for abiding and severe punishments for refusing.
Decree of Return to The Village
Nobles will now be expected to raise sizable retinues. Those who do so are referred to as yoriki.
Nobles and other landowners will have exclusive rights to hunt in fields.
Landowners as well as holders of sea routes will be granted the right to collect tolls on commerce.
The most prestigious samurai clans are preferred when entrusting lords with armies.
Each notable yields 0.1 influence per day to the settlement's owner clan{newline}Tax from fortifications 5% decreased

Long-standing disputes over land boundaries, water rights, mountain rights, or any other disagreements between parties can be exhaustive. By allowing the ruler final judgment, these issues can be resolved quickly.
Dominion can be concentrated within the domain by arranging powerful positions in the territory with people closely related to the ruling clan.

Creditors and financiers can be commanded to release those with debt, providing relief to impoverished fiefdoms. Doing so will help the livelihood of those in need but will be detrimental to parts of the domain's economy.

Establishes a lawsuit suggestion box to guarantee the right of a court trial for peasants. Doing this will prevent accusations of unjustness by local officials and prevent disputes among residents from escalating into violence.

Local lords can grant temples, shrines, samurai, and wealthy peasants the right to manage the forests on behalf of the community. Allowing this would promote resource management, prevent competition for timber, and avert the destruction of mountainous areas.

Promotes cultural activites such as tea ceremony, Renga poetry, Noh drama, etc., and stimulate exchanges between feudal lords. This brought together feudal lords, court nobles, and merchants to increase their power, but it was not good for those who were considered uncultured.

Villages can be given more autonomy, becoming more cohesive by establishing village codes and laws. This can lead to unchecked power amongst the village leadership, reducing the influence of lords, which can lead to conflicts between the two parties.

Orders can be issued to the population to take up arms and prepare for war, no matter if they are a peasant, merchant, or an artisan. They may not be the best of forces, but they are better than nothing.

Sending troops throughout the realm to confiscate weapons will help to decrease the chance of successful rebellions. This also divides the classes of commoners and nobility even further by allowing samurai to keep their armaments, but not peasants.

Establishing a census for villages and expelling new residents. Bandits and troublesome ronin will have difficulties taking root in the area. It will severely limit the growth of villages but will lower the chances of banditry in the area.

Heeding the counsel of foreign advisors will open up new ideas and relations with external powers. This will help with foreign relations and trade but nobles may distrust the spread of outside influence.

Utilizing family as a bargaining tool is an effective way to solidify the relations between factions and ensure that treatises are obeyed. Hostages will dramatically assist in matters of diplomacy but will cause a loss to the faction's influence.

With religious influence reaching far across the lands, more fanatical followers will emerge. Fostering this kind of religious fervor will help to encourage religious leaders to donate more men to fight on behalf of lords whose beliefs align with their own.

Opportunities in trade with distant regions and the need to bolster the quality of naval vessels mean that the priority of high-quality resources should rest with shipbuilders. The faction's territory will see cheaper and faster ships to craft, as well as an increase in growth to port cities, at the cost of income from villages.
donating lands for use by religious sects
Lords can donate some of their territory to religious sects. Territories donated this way are difficult to take away, even for rulers.

Settlement prosperity increases by 2 per day{newline}Clans lose 1 influence per day{newline}Tax income in settlements are increased by 15%{newline}Settlement loyalty is decreased by 1 per day{newline}Settlement Security is decreased by 1 per day{newline}Each notable yields -.25 influence per day to the settlement's owner clan{newline}Access to Naval Cannons during sieges

Opening local markets to exotic imports will introduce unique wares, technology, and culture to the region. Even though new export and import opportunities will arise, some notables and merchants may harbor disdain for the competition to domestic trade.
Settlement prosperity decreases by 2 per day{newline}Tax income in settlements are decreased by 5%{newline}Allows access to Ammo Caches during offensive sieges

To prevent supply complications during siege operations, towns will need to give up some of their supplies intended for the markets. Doing so will allow for supplies to be prioritized for offensive sieges, but will also cause negative impacts to prosperity in towns.

You demanded all of {QUEST_GIVER.LINK}'s son's goods. The swords are yours, but you can no longer complete {QUEST_GIVER.LINK}'s task, as you have stolen their entire shipment.
Wait. I don’t want to fight, I’m leaving.
Search for {HERO.LINK}'s heirloom and bring it back to him
How dare you? How about you run {DISTANCE} units, just for fun.
The artisan pointed out the rough position to where the bandits might be, hunt them down
Glorious! The congregation will be forever grateful! We will pray for your safe and swift return !Vá com Deus!
Hail Sir! What brings you to me
I am looking for a certain someones belonging he said that he was robbed around here so the robbers surely had to try to sell it quickly
Is that true? Well, that is interesting. Just some days ago a group of ragged looking men came around the market to try to sell off what seemed a pretty valuable item
Really? Did you see where did they take off to?

I did not really wanted to get into any trouble so I did not look, BUT there's rumors of a certain bandit hideout nearby if you think those are your guys you can take your chances and look for it (Quest END)
So, did you recover my heirloom?
Yes I did. Now give me my reward
Ok Great. Now leave. Here's your reward
Actually no, I won't give it to you unless you pay me well
What?!!! You SNAKE here take it and never come back
You know what, why shouldn't I keep it?
What?!!! You THIEF get out of here right now
We have run into some trouble trying to create a place of worship for the newly converted.Perhaps you might be willing to assist us ?
Yeah sure padre, tell me what to do!

The people of this land have been asking for a new church; one to instil the blessings of The Lord on the faithful and those who have yet to accept Christ into their hearts.A few men have been hired to help build this new place of worship, however, their hands are idle; a shipment of building materials destined for us never arrived.I have heard of bandits and thieves making off with folks' property, but to steal from The Lord, how terrible. I pray that you might help us retrieve what we have lost.
Don't worry, we will bring the name of god to all these lands

This is the amount of cargo your navy can transport. You need more cargo capacity than your total inventory weight to set sail.
