Ships in this left side will be scuttled and destroyed.
This is the total daily upkeep of your fleet.

A scroll filled with techniques and diagrams of swordsmanship in the Kage-ryū style. Developed in 1438 by Aisu Hisatada, Kage-ryū has established itself as one of the three major origins for the evolution of sword based-martial arts.
A scroll detailing the techniques of the Shintō-ryū style, a school of swordsmanship founded by Iizasa Ienao and now counted among the three main origins of the martial arts.
A scroll describing the Shinkage-ryū style swordsmanship style, a school established by Kamiizumi Nobutsuna as a derivative of the Kage-ryū style.
This scroll summarises the swordsmanship techniques of the Ten-ryū style, a martial arts school that also includes polearms, throwing and jūjutsu.
A scroll that describes the techniques of the Toda-ryū style of swordsmanship, a school founded by Itō Kagehisa after visiting Kanemaki Michimune, a master of the Nakajo-ryū style
This scroll contains the teachings of Marume Nagayoshi, a disciple of the Shintō-ryū style and founder of the Marumeshinkage-ryū school of swordsmanship.
A scroll depicting the techniques of Hōzōin-ryū school, a spear martial arts specialised in the use of the Jumonji sickle spear to enable diverse offensive and defensive techniques.
A book written by Ogasawara Mochinaga, master of archery for Shogun Ashikaga Yoshinori, that explains how to handle the bow and what to do when it is broken.
This book contains the secret archery techniques of the Takeda Clan, passed down for generations and written down by Takeda Motonobu, head of a junior branch of the clan.
This book describes the horseriding technique of the Ōtsubo-ryū school, one of the classical schools of horsemanship that counts the Ashikaga Shoguns among its practitioners.
This scroll details the medicinal method of horse breeding and contains a depiction of the patron god of horse doctors as well as medicinal herbs used as horse medicine.

This scroll contains the teachings of the Anzai-ryū school of horse medicine and describes the relationship between esoteric philosophy and horse diseases, including the methods and effects of treatment with acupuncture.
This book describes the secrets of horse treatment written by Kuwashima Hirotsuna and provides details on the parts of the horse's body and various methods of moxibustion treatment.
A book containing the teachings of Hachijō Fusashige, founder of the Hachijo-ryu school of horsemanship.
This book by Ogasawara Mochinaga, master of archery for Shogun Ashikaga Yoshinori, describes the manners and techniques of the Yabusame mounted archery.
This book by Ogasawara Motonaga, son of Mochinaga master of archery for the Ashikaga Shogunate, details the manners and techniques of the Kasagake mounted archery.
This book by Ogasawara Mochinaga, master of archery for Shogun Ashikaga Yoshinori, describes the manners and techniques of the Inuoumono mounted archery.
This scroll contains a secret gunpowder recipe, originally sent by Ōtomo Sōrin, and describes the method of preparation, precautions and proportions of ingredients.
This scroll describes the production of gunpowder techniques of the Tsuda-ryū school of artillery.
This scroll explains how to produce gun ammunition and more than 30 different types of balls, including balls made by connecting several balls with a wire and hollow balls.
A book describing the art of gunnery. Written by Karaudo Chikahiro, a firearm instructor for the Jimbo clan.

A set of scrolls describing the art of gunnery of the Kishiwada-ryū school of gunnery, written by Yoshida Morisada. The book details proper firing techniques and gunpowder recipes. The scroll also includes many descriptions from a spiritual perspective, linking guns with esoteric Buddhism and the role of guns in expelling evil demons
A scroll containing over three decades of esoteric iconography and scriptures, assembled by Kintaibō Kakuzen. Contains over one hundred volumes and is one of the largest collections of its kind.

A scroll containing the different scholastic and oral traditions from various schools of esoteric Buddhism, organized into two hundred twenty-eight volumes. Organized by Gokurakubō Jōchō, taking over thirty years to compile.

A scroll containing the oral traditions, events, and manners from various schools of esoteric Buddhism. Organized by Sōkushoin Koshu, a learned monk of the Tendai sect, who ascended Mount Hiei to study the unique sects of Buddhism.
A book of scrolls compiling rituals and doctrines related to mountain ascetic practices of Shugendo. Written by Akyubou Sokuden, a mountain ascetic from Mount Nikko.
A book of letters testifying to the transmission of ritual doctrine in Shugendo. Written by Akyubou Sokuden, a mountain ascetic from Mount Nikko.

Five volumes authored by, Utsunomiya Sadamune,an officer in charge of managing the Katana of the Shogun Ashikaga Yoshimitsu. He categorized katana by period and presented a genealogy of katana smiths, as well as famous swords and their measurements.
A scroll containing a list of names of katana smiths by region. Includes each smith’s inscriptions, weapon characteristics, anecdotes, and genealogical information.
A book finished by Saitō Toshimasa, started by his father, that covers around eight hundred forty Katana. Includes Katana from Awataguchi, Soshu, Chugoku-Shikoku, Hokuriku, Bizen-Bicchu, and Kyushu.
A book classifying katana smiths in different countries into five levels of evaluation and includes highlights of their blades, the date of their production, and examples of famous swords.
A book describing beliefs, origins, and history of the mountains of the Kinki region.

A book composed of experiences traveling from to Kamakura to Kyoto in 1223. It is filled with phrases from old Chinese texts, poetry, Buddhist writings, as well as detailed descriptions of landscapes and landmarks.
A travelogue book composed of experiences on the way from Higashiyama, Kyoto to Kamakura in 1242. It is filled with detailed descriptions of landscapes.

A collection of diary entries written by Abutsuni, consort of Fujiwara no Tameie. The entries focused on her travels from Kyoto to Kamakura to appeal to the Kamakura Shogunate over a territorial dispute between her son and his half-brother.

A book, written by Shōgoin Dōkō, cataloging various materials of his travels on the Hokuriku Route. Includes various writings on the Ōshū region, multiple kinds of poems, legends, and writings on historical sites.
A book describing the life and culture of the warriors and provinces of Japan during the Muromachi period.
A collection of studies on Japan’s geography, customs, manners, and natural history. Written by Tei Shunkō who was sent to Japan to help in the suppression of Japanese Pirates.

A book detailing the relations between Korea and Japan, prepared by the Yi Dynasty diplomat Shin Suk-ju. It records the politics of Japan and Ryukyu, including history of diplomatic exchanges and reception of envoys.
A Japanese book on the military strategy established at the end of the Heian period. It was created as a supplementary military book to the writings of Sun Tzu.

This book is revered as one of China's major military strategy books, written by Sonshi. With advances in organized conflict, this text has become increasingly important for strategists across Japan. Utilized as a source for the writings of Takeda Shingen.
This book is revered as one of China's major military strategy books, written by Goshi. With advances in organized conflict, this text has become increasingly important for strategists across Japan.
Revered as one of China's major military strategy books. With advances in organized conflict, this text has become increasingly important for strategists across Japan.

A book on the theories of writing renga, written by the court noble Nijō Yoshimoto. It describes the history and rules of renga, the spirit of renga creation, attire, and how to organize renga meetings.

A book on the theories of writing Muromachi period renga, written by the renga master Sōgi. It describes the history of renga and the techniques of renga creation in a question-and-answer style, with examples.
This book is a collection of two thousand fifty-two renga poems, many written by samurai. Compiled by Ichijō Fuyuyoshi, Sanjōnishi Sanetaka, Sōgi and others.

Written by the monk Gen’e, this book is an assortment of diverse knowledge and education necessary for social life. The contents cover food, clothing, housing, occupations, territorial management, architecture, judiciary practices, professions, Buddhism, armor, culture, and recuperation.

Written by the nobleman Ichijō Kaneyoshi, this book is an assortment of miscellaneous information. Includes details on the social life of samurai and court nobles, horses, armor, blacksmithing, temples, famous painters, alcoholic beverages, landmarks, memorial services, teas, and much more.

Written by the nobleman Ichijō Kaneyoshi, this book is a compilation of Shinto and Buddhist Rituals, worship, processions, events, clothing, secret banquets, bad luck rites, imperial edicts, and other miscellaneous writings.

A collection of explanations into the manners and systems of the Muromachi Shogunate’s warrior class, including accounts of negotiations between court nobles and samurai. Authored by Ise Sadamachi, governor of Yamashiro Province.
A story describing the contrasts between the Taira and Minamoto, their subsequent battles and downfalls, and the human drama of the Heian Nobles.
An eight volume narrative on Minamoto no Yoshitsune and his followers.
A book detailing the accession of Emperor Go-Daigo. Includes the fall of the Kamakura Shogunate, and the new government and its collapse.
A Kamukura period biographical story based on the revenge of the Soga brothers in Fujino. Written in the style of a military history treatise.
A collection of four books on Confucious thought and five books on assorted poems, documents, rites, and other texts. It was possibly compiled in some way by Confucious himself.
An Encyclopaedia by Minamoto no Shitagō, containing about three thousand entries on his opinions of various matters.

A book of six hundred twenty articles filled with miscellaneous meanings of Japanese and Chinese words and phrases. Includes celestial phenomena, deities, countries, inner regions, geography, plants, grass, birds, beasts and insects, human affairs, the human body, Buddhism, treasures, clothing, musical instruments, miscellaneous items, food and drink, and more.
An Encyclopaedia of the Middle Ages, authored by Tōin Kinkata. Includes astronomy, geography, the divisions of court, literature, manners and customs, arts and crafts, religion, and taboos.
An Encyclopaedia by Tōroku Hanō with eighteen sections on society, seasonal events, quantities, language, human ethics, and more.
A scroll filled with an assortment of writings. Includes astronomy, geography, literature, divisions of court, customs, goods, arts and crafts, religion, and taboos.

A collection of thirty-one articles codifying the customary laws of maritime traders in the Seto Inland Sea. Includes regulations for ships, shipowners, sailors, maritime salvage, and nautical rituals.

Fifty-one articles comprising the codes of the Kamakura shogunate. Filled with diverse content including the duties of guardians and landowners and codifies unique samurai jurisprudence that differs from the traditional court law and manor law.

A commentary on the shogunate's basic code of law, the Goseibaishikimoku, authored by Kiyohara no Nobukata. The contents contain quotes and explanations of the various theories of kōke law and discusses the blending of different kōke laws within samurai families.

Seventeen articles consisting of laws authored by Asakura Takakage, given to his heir Ujikage. The contents cover directives on the control of vassals, recruitment of personnel, strengthening of military power, emphasis on civil administration, fostering of territorial culture, strictness of justice, and vigilance against other domains.

An assorted set of laws written by Date Tanemune detailing a number of regulations on the governance of his territory. It is characterized by detailed provisions on criminal offenses such as murder and robbery, the broad recognition of landowners' right to rule, and preferential treatment in the sale and purchase of land to craftsmen of arms and farming implements.

An article of law written by Imagawa Yoshimoto detailing a number of regulations on the governance of his territory. It provides stipulation on relations between lords and peasants, boundary disputes, responses in case of conflicts and banditry, restrictions on the sale and purchase of territory, provisions for the vassal system, non-interventionist rights, and inheritance and court procedures, and much more.

A set of laws written by Harunobu Takeda for the realms under the control of the Takeda Clan. A total of fifty-five articles, It stipulates the prohibition of private wars, the regulation of letters to other domains, the prohibition of sectarian disputes, and the prohibition of private alliances.

A set of laws written by Sagara Haruhiro for the realms under the control of the Sagara Clan. Includes stipulations on the sale and purchase of rice fields, master-servant relations, water access, fines for sheltering fugitives, and prohibits the Ikko sect. Prayers by anyone other than Buddhists, Shinto, or mountain dwelling priests are strictly prohibited.
A medical treatise compiled by Izumo no Hirosada from the Heian period, sporting a collection of medicinal herbs across the region.

A medical treatise compiled by Tamba Yasuyori, a doctor of acupuncture who served as court physician during the Heian period. It compiled into thirty volumes and consists of doctors' ethics, general medical theory, therapies for various diseases, health and hygiene regimen, medical techniques and medical thought.

A leading medical treatise of the Kamakura period, compiled by the physician Kajiwara Shōzen. Kajiwara utilized his knowledge of medicine and references from the latest Chinese Medical texts of the period to assemble this set of volumes. Includes details on vast amount of illnesses and diagrams of internal organs.
Kajiwara Shōzen’s medical treatise written around 1313 and entirely in Chinese. Intended to transmit and preserve the art of medicine.

Ten volumes of Yū Sōritsu’s Ming dynasty medical texts reprinted and published by Asaino Sōzui, a merchant in Sakai. Intended for en-masse sale, this collection is vital for spreading knowledge on a plethora of ailments.

A set of eight volumes on diseases and treatments by Manaze Dōzan. Contains information on diverse etiologies from ancient and modern Chinese sources and is vital for the cataloging and treating of numerous ailments across Japan.

A comprehensive collection of articles on the methods and procedures of castle building. Inside are detailed descriptions of the material, manpower, and techniques required of castles depending on their terrain and complexity.

Sou Kouryo's completed collection of Shu military writings from the Song Dynasty. Each volume is filled with theories and doctrines on assorted military knowledge as well as descriptions of various siege engines and defensive equipment.

A postbattle location is the result of two armies clashing on the battlefield, leaving dead bodies on the ground. These bodies have armor and weapons that can be worth a fortune, but acquiring these items come at a serious risk. Scavengers will come from all over to plunder and loot the items, and you must compete with others to get as much as you can and get out before you are overwhelmed.{newline}{newline}A post battle can appear when two armies clash and a certain threshold of casualties take place, which is customizable in the options. When entering a post battle, you can select a small number of troops to accompany you. The number of troops you can bring in is dependent on the Roguery skill. Once inside, other looters will be there, collecting the loot of the previous battle. There are several loot piles on the map, which can be interacted with to loot the items. If you press “Alt”, you can see the location of all the loot piles. You can command your troops to loot the piles as well by telling them to do so as a command. Select the formation and left click on the pile you want them to loot.{newline}{newline}Enemy looters are focused on the loot and will only attack the player if they interrupt their looting, or if the player has looted a lot and they want to take it for themselves. These looters are more cowardly than normal troops and will be likely to flee if wounded. The enemy looters will the piles, stealing potential loot from you for themselves, so you must race to get as much loot as possible, or you can attack them for their loot if you’re brave enough. You can also leave them alone, focus on getting as much as you can, and get out by exiting the area and retreating through the red barrier like a normal map. You will keep any loot collected if you retreat this way.{newline}{newline}More enemies will show up over time, equipped with ranged weapons and better armor. They will target the player if the player has loot, so be careful and try not to stay too long or you’ll be overwhelmed.

Guns played a key part in this period of Japanese history. The designs were imported from the west and mass produced in Japan. Known as Tanegashima guns, they were musket-based matchlocks that proved extremely deadly and were able to penetrate Japanese armor with ease. Shokuho has a wide variety of guns, including pistols, muskets, and even an Ozutsu, a small handheld cannon.{newline}{newline}Guns deal high damage, and are highly accurate with the right skills, but are slow to reload. Gunners are vulnerable to cavalry charges, so keep them protected with melee infantry. If you are having trouble dealing with gun troops, try baiting a volley fire from them at a distance, and quickly close the distance with cavalry to disrupt their reloading.{newline}{newline}Gun wielding troops in the first line of a formation will crouch, so the 2nd line in the formation can fire over them. The player may also fire a gun while crouching. Firing a gun while crouching is more accurate. This happens automatically for troops in formation and works even if there are archer troops in the formation as well.

Due to Japan being made up of several islands, boats are required to travel between them. This can be done at ports. There are dozens of ports around Japan. To travel around Japan, you will need to acquire boats. Ports are where you buy or build boats. Larger boats will require them to be built, which takes time. You can see boats in production in the Naval Management screen, which can be accessed by pressing H or clicking the icon in the bottom left corner of the screen.{newline}{newline}Once you have enough boats to carry your army, you can go on the water by clicking the “Set Sail” button. If you can’t afford to buy boats, you can also take a ferry, which will take you to a specific port you choose. The ferry will cost more money depending on how many troops you have in your party, and how much your party is carrying. Finally, ports are where you buy or build boats. Larger boats will require them to be built, which takes time. You can see boats in production in the Naval Management screen.

Naval battles are a custom feature unique to Shokuho. It has been designed from scratch to feel like the naval battles of 16th century Japan.{newline}{newline}Naval battles work in custom battles and in the Campaign. For custom battles, boats are chosen automatically based on the number of troops selected for each side. For campaign battles, there is a custom UI to let the player choose which boats they want to select, and which troops go in what specific ship the player selects.All naval battles happen on the open ocean, with each side starting apart from each other. The player can control their ships with simple commands. Each ship has their own formation. The player can tell a ship to move to a specific point by giving the move order command while selecting that ship’s formation. They can also tell ships to charge, causing them to sail towards the nearest enemy ship. If you order a ship to target a specific enemy formation, they will sail towards that specific ship. You can also tell a ship to stop by issuing the stop order. All other movement orders have no function in naval battles.{newline}{newline}You can pilot the ship manually by walking up to the pilot position, near the rear of each ship, and using it. You can steer it by using the movement keys.{newline}{newline}Ships can be sunk and lost. A ship can be sunk by taking too much damage, and almost certainly guaranteeing the death of any crew on board. The most common way of a ship sinking is through collision damage. A ship getting repeatedly collided with will cause a lot of damage, and if a ship takes enough damage, it will begin to sink. Guns can also do a large amount of damage to ships. When a ship starts sinking, it will slowly fill up with water until it is below the surface completely. If one of your ships sinks, even if you win the battle, it will be removed from your list of available ships. Losing a naval battle will also force you to lose all the ships brought into the battle.{newline}{newline}Any agent that falls in the water will drown and die. This is accompanied by a custom drowning animation. This is part of why a sinking ship is so deadly for any troops inside.{newline}{newline}Boarding is the main way to fight in naval battles. Two ships can be boarded when they are near each other, not moving, and facing the same parallel direction. Boarding can happen with ships facing opposite direction, or the same direction. Once boarding begins, the ships will slowing start to align next to each other until they line up, then they will strafe towards each other until they collide. Once this happens, boarding begins, and troops on one boat will begin to board the other. The troops who board are decided by whether the player is issuing the charge command on that formation or not. The player can also board by pressing the use key on the side of the ship that is touching the other ship, which will place them on the other ship. Once all the troops on one side are dead, the troops will head back to their ship and positions and sail out again to find another ship to attack{newline}{newline}{newline}{newline}{newline}{newline}.

Duel locations are spread out across Japan. You can enter these locations and initiate a duel with a duelist. These are intended to be more difficult one on one fights, and they also have some cinematics, along with beautiful, handcrafted scenes to set the tone. Winning a duel will give you renown and respect throughout Japan.

Temples are neutral settlements where the player and AI can recruit special temple related troops, buy books from temples which can improve skills, or donate to temples to improve relations. There are several subtypes of temples based on several distinct religions. Donating to a temple improves the relations with that specific temple, along with every temple following that specific religion.

The camp feature lets the player interact with their army in interesting ways. Here you can promote troops to companions, select a book to read, or simply wait and let your army recover. Waiting in a camp recovers health faster than out in the open, but slower than waiting in a settlement.

Books can be bought and read to improve skills. You can select which book to read through the camp feature. Reading a book happens over time naturally. Reading a book while waiting, whether in a settlement or the camp, increases the reading speed. There are dozens of book types, some extremely rare that can even offer focus points to the player.

Troops that perform well in battle can be promoted to companions. After a battle you will receive a notification that a troop or some troops are ready to promote. To promote a troop, enter the camp and select the promote troop option. Here you will see a list of troops available to promote, with their skills on the left side of the screen. Selecting them and hitting the promote button will make them a companion. Hitting the reward button will give all troops of that type an XP boost, but they will no longer be promotable.

The enlistment feature lets you enlist with a lord as a normal troop, much like troops do with the player’s party. To enlist in a lord’s party, simply choose the “I wish to enlist in your army” dialogue option. You will follow the lord’s army and engage in battles they engage in. Overtime you will earn XP and promote to the next unit. You will be given equipment based on your troop, or you can equip your own equipment that you find if you prefer that. When at peace time, your lord may order a mock battle to take place between two sides of the lord’s party. This is a way for you to gain valuable experience without being at war. Once you reach the noble tier of troops (tier 4), you will start receiving tasks from your lord, where you will be asked to leave the party and complete them. Such tasks include scouting enemy settlements, picking up supplies from towns, engaging enemy parties, or when at peace, dealing with looters. Once you reach the max tier of troop and gain enough XP, it will be possible to become a direct vassal of the clan you are enlisted with, even if your renown is lower than normally possible to become a vassal.

Shinto, meaning "way of the spirits", is Japan's ancestral native religion, rooted in nature and spiritualism. Followers of Shinto worship the Kami, the spirits that inhabit all things, from towering mountains to flowing rivers. Shinto shrines, often found in groves or on mountaintops, serve as places of worship and are tended to by both priests and priestesses who act as keepers of spiritual traditions and intermediaries between humans and spirits.

Rinzai Buddhism is a sect of Zen Buddhism, a disciplined and austere path to enlightenment that focuses not only on study but on sudden insight through rigorous meditation and riddles. Introduced to Japan from the continent centuries ago , Rinzai has long held sway among the warrior elite and has flourished in monasteries , often fortified, where many monks train in martial arts, seeing no contradiction between sword and spirit.

Shingon Buddhism is one of the major schools of Buddhism in Japan, tracing its roots in the esoteric teachings of Tang China. Shingon embraces ritual, symbolism, and mystical practices to bring the faithful closer to enlightenment, while monks serve as keepers of the sacred mandalas, mantras, and mudras that are used to unlock wisdom.

Tendai Buddhism is one of the oldest and most prestigious Buddhist schools in Japan, boasting ancient and deep ties with the Imperial Court in Kyoto. Established on sacred Mount Hiei, where the main temple Enryaku-ji is located, Tendai teachings present a comprehensive system open to both elite and commoner, as monks study the Lotus Sutra as the highest truth, teaching that all beings may attain Buddhahood. On the other hand, the Tendai great monasteries, have become formidable power centers in their own right, some aable to field armies of warrior-monks.

Soto Buddhism is a sect of Zen Buddhism, often considered the quieter sibling to Rinzai, that emphasizes patient, silent sitting, or "just sitting", as the true expression of enlightenment. Spreading more among rural folk and modest temples, Soto has fewer ties to lords and warriors, instead favouring service to village communities and secluded monastic life, Soto monks being known for their simplicity.

Shin Buddhism is the youngest school of Buddhism in Japan, established by former Tendai monk Shinran. Also known as Jodo Shinshu, meaning True Pure Land, Shin Buddhism rejects elitism in favour of faith accessible to all, teaching that enlightenment cannot be achieved through effort or meditation alone, but through sincere trust in Buddha. Thanks to this approach, Shin Buddhism has spread widely among commoners weary of the constant wars between daimyos. In some provinces, leagues of peasant believers, known as ikkō-ikki, have taken up arms to defend their faith and their land, challenging samurai rule.

Strategically located in the westernmost part of the San'yō region, near the Kanmon Straits that separate Honshu from Kyushu, Kushizaki is a port castle town originally by the Naitō clan, from which it is possible to control the sea and the flow of trade and people across the western provinces.

Positioned near the confluence of several key trade routes in the Chūgoku region, the castle town of Sanbonmatsu has become a target for expanding warlords. While its military importance seems negligible, its location along vital supply routes makes it a key target for forces looking to consolidate control over the region.

Originally built as a small fortified residence for the Mōri clan this coastal castle town grew in importance along with the expansion of its inhabitants' power, while its hilltop location ensures control over the surrounding territories and sea routes.

Iwami is famed for its rich silver mines, which have made it one of the most valuable settlements in Japan. The most powerful daimyos of the region have long battled for control of the Iwami ginzan, which has most recently fallen to the Mōri clan.

Gassantoda is a castle town in San'in that traces its origins back to the Kamakura period and before that to the Heian period when a fortress was built to protect trade routes and the renowned local steel production. More recently, Gassantoda became the stage for the last stand of the once dominant Amago clan against the ascendant Ōuchi and Mōri clans, with the conquest by Mōri Motonari marking the definitive shift of power in the region.

Okayama is a castle town located in the western part of the Chūgoku region, providing both military and economic advantages through access to maritime trade routes and strategic passage between Honshu and Shikoku

Ichijodani is a fortified town in western Hokuriku, surrounded on all sides by the natural defences of rivers and mountains, making it a difficult target for any besieger. Built by the Asakura clan, Ichijodani has grown into a centre of culture, craftsmanship and religion thanks to the hospitality afforded by the Asakura clan to refugees fleeing Kyoto during the Ōnin War, making it a jewel rivaling the Imperial Capital itself.

Originally a fortified temple complex of the Kaga Ikko movement, Oyama has evolved into a significant stronghold in the Hokuriku region and its strategic and religious value has drawn the attention of powerful neighbors.

A Nanao, the stronghold of the Hatakeyama clan, is one of the most important castle towns along the Noto Peninsula. Surrounded by mountains and the sea, its defenses are strong, and its harbor allows for active maritime trade.

Perched atop a steep mountain, the castle town of Kasugayama was originally a possession of the Nagao clan, but has served as the seat of the powerful Uesugi clan since Uesugi Kenshin, born a Nagao, took over. Kenshin turned Kasugayama into a center of military power in Echigo from which he departed several times at the head of his armies to challenge the Takeda clan.

Situated on the coast of Echigo Province, Niigata is a prosperous port town benefiting from maritime trade and fertile agricultural lands. The Shinano River provides an essential route for transporting rice and goods inland. The town falls under the influence of Uesugi Kenshin, whose strong rule ensures stability in the region. Fishermen, salt merchants, and shipbuilders contribute to Niigata’s economy, making it an important asset for Kenshin’s war efforts.

Fukashi is a castle town built amongst the mountains of Shinano to protect the domains of the Ogasawara clan until it was taken over by its parent clan following a famous siege by Takeda Shingen, who subsequently converted it into one of the outposts of the expanding Takeda clan.

Kōfu, a castle town in the heart of Kai Province in the southern part of the Tōsan region, has been the home of the Takena clan since its beginnings, but has only recently grown considerably thanks to Takeda Shingen, who has made it the centre of his expanding domain and undertaken major flood control projects to increase agricultural production and quality of life

Sunpu has served as the seat of the powerful Imagawa clan for decades, during which the castle town has flourished as a center of governance, trade and culture, benefiting from its location along the strategic Tōkaidō road. However, the Imagawa’s power has declined significantly since their crushing defeat at the hands of Oda Nobunaga exposing Sunpu and other Imagawa domains to the thirst for conquest of neighbouring lords.

Hamamatsu is a castle town in Tokai, built by the Imagawa clan to guard the access the access to the vital Tōkaidō highway, it was then taken over by the rising Tokugawa Ieyasu in the aftermath of the battle of Okehazama.

Okazaki, the birthplace of the rising lord Tokugawa Ieyasu, is a vital castle town in Mikawa Province. Under Tokugawa rule, it has been reinforced as a military base, securing the clan’s control over the region. The castle town is flourishing, with a growing population of samurai, merchants, and craftsmen. Its position along the Tōkaidō road makes it an essential stop for travelers and military movements.

Built in the Kamakura period to guard the highways between Kyoto and the Shogunal capital, Kiyosu has long been the seat of the Oda clan of Owari and the site of political intrigue and military conflicts surrounding the clan, at least until the young lord Oda Nobunaga chose to move his seat to Gifu. Although the relocation of the court weakened its position, Kiyosu remains an important fortified city bustling with activity.

“The one who controls Gifu controls Japan” is a common saying that emphasises the strategic location of this castle town. Once a possession of the Saitō clan and recently seized by Oda Nobunaga, who chose to rename it after the legendary mountain where most of ancient china was unified and the birthplace of Confucious, signalling to everyone his intention to unify the whole of Japan.

A Odawara, the stronghold of the powerful Hojo clan, stands as an impregnable fortress in the Kanto region. With its vast network of walls, moats, and outlying fortifications, it is considered one of the most well-defended castles in Japan. The city below is a thriving center of trade, with merchants, farmers, and artisans benefiting from Hojo governance. Odawara’s strategic location allows the Hojo to control access to eastern Japan, ensuring their dominance over the region.

Originally developed from a small fishing village as a fortified residence for a local noble of the Heian Period, Edo was later fortified to become the castle town that currently towers over the Musashino Plateau and Edo Bay. The recent turmoil in Kantō has seen Edo shift between the different warring Clans and has severely hampered its development, but the city still retains its enormous potential.

Originally the seat of the namesake clan, Ota is a castle town in Kantō in close proximity to the vital Tōkaidō road, which connects the region to the capital Kyoto, making it an important military and administrative center.

First built in the Heian period, the castle town of Utsunomiya was the seat of the clan of the same name for centuries and one of the most important centres in the Kantō region which exerts control over many of the local land routes.

Built as the fortified residence of the Nagano clan, the castle town of Minowa has long been a critical stronghold for the control of the surrounding region, which made it a mandatory target in the confrontation between the Uesugi and Takeda clans, until the forces of Takeda Shingen seized Minowa resulting in the demise of the Nagano clan and the death of all its members.

Himeji was originally built in the early Muromachi period by the Akamatsu clan as a small fortified outpost atop Himeyama Hill and along the western route to capital Kyoto, but underwent several demolitions and reconstructions until it reached its present form as a mighty castle town barring the way to would-be invaders.

Dominated by the temple fortress of Ishiyama Hongan-ji, Osaka has grown into a major center of religious and economic activity. The temple fortress, controlled by the militant Ikkō-ikki, serves as the stronghold of the Jōdo Shinshū sect, resisting the rule of samurai warlords.

Sakai, one of the wealthiest and most autonomous cities in Japan, thrives as a center of commerce. The city’s merchant guilds operate independently of the warring daimyōs, maintaining direct trade with China and Portuguese traders. Famous for its high-quality firearms, swords, and luxury goods, Sakai’s economy flourishes even as war ravages the surrounding regions.

Once the great imperial capital of Japan, Nara remains a center of Buddhist influence and cultural heritage. The massive temples of Tōdaiji and Kōfukuji stand as reminders of its former glory, housing powerful monastic factions.

Kyoto, once the unrivaled capital of Japan, emerged almost completely destroyed by the struggles for control over the central power. The authority of the Ashikaga Shogunate has crumbled, leaving the city at the mercy of the warring daimyos, while the Imperial Court sits back and watches helplessly. Nevertheless, Kyoto remains the depository of secular traditions and while its days as the true centre of power seem to be over, its religious and cultural influence persists.

A seemingly quiet castle town built atop Mount Kinugasa, Kannonji has been repeatedly embroiled in the conflicts of its ancestral owners, the Rokkaku clan, and only the castle’s natural defenses have allowed it to resist several sieges.

Built as the fortified seat of the Azai clan to rule over the surrounding region, the castle town of Odani sits atop a steep ridge, its defenses making it a formidable stronghold, while its position along key trade routes ensure the growing prosperity of the settlement.
Koyama is strategic stronghold in Southern Kyushu, nestled in the rugged terrain of Osumi Province, where mountain passes connect inland domains to the western coast.

A small but strategically located settlement, Uchi serves as a waypoint for travelers and merchants moving through its province. The town’s location makes it valuable to any daimyo seeking control over the surrounding region.

The castle town of Sadowara, located in the southern portion of Kyushu, has served as the seat of the Itō clan for generations. Benefiting from fertile plains and proximity to maritime routes, Sadowara has flourished as both an administrative and agricultural center becoming the epicenter of the Itō clan's expansion attempts in the region.

A castle town nestled deep in the mountains of South-western Kyushu, Hitoyoshi has served as the seat of the Sagara clan since the Kamakura period. It is said that during the construction work a moon-shaped stone was unearthed, thus giving rise to the alternative folk name of moon castle. Popular tales aside, Hitoyoshi stands as an imposing fortification that has only once been attacked by an enemy and with a fatal outcome.

Benefiting from its position along key maritime trade routes and its proximity to the island’s northern provinces, Nyushima has grown into a prosperous castle town, also thanks to the influence of the Ōtomo clan, that has promoted the town as a center of local governance.

Nestled within the rugged highlands of northern Kyushu, Kiidani has long served as a fortified settlement, guarding the access to the western island of Japan. Its position overlooking vital inland routes has given it strategic relevance amid the growing contest for control over Kyushu and has already turned Kiidani into a conflict point between the Ouchi and Otomo in the past.

Located in north-western Kyushu, Yanagawa is strategically located on the banks of the Chikugo River, at the crossroads of trade routes connecting much of the region, which facilitates both trade and military movements.

Well-positioned between coastal trade routes and mountain strongholds of western Kyushu, Kumamoto has enjoyed steady growth thanks to the flow of trade and local production that made it a thriving and well-defended castle town.

Perched on a prominent hill in northern Kyushu, Tachibanayama was originally built for its namesake Tachibana clan as a fortified town, whose control over the surrounding areas remains vital for securing key trade routes and access to both land and sea.

Muranaka has long served as a local stronghold in Western Kyushu, functioning as a minor seat of governance under the protection of the Aso clan, whose authority once extended across the central highlands. With the Aso clan’s power sharply declined under pressure from the Shimazu to the south and the Ōtomo to the east, Muranaka is now left vulnerable.

The castle town of Hinoe sits on the west coast of Kyushu on the Shimabara Peninsula. Built in the early Kamakura period, Hinoe has since served as the home base and major source of profits for the Arima clan, who from here controlled maritime trade routes and more recently the Nanban foreign trade.
Nakamura, is a castle town in Western Shikoku. Surrounded by rivers and mountains, it enjoys a natural defensive advantage, benefitting from the fertile lands that produce rice and timber.
Located in the inland reaches of Shikoku, Kurose is a strategically placed castle town that provides control over the inland routes and a valuable defensive position against neighbouring domains.

Yuzuki is a fortified port town in western Shikoku, built by the Kōno clan as as a gateway to maritime commerce. Despite its modest size, Yuzuki has prospered thanks to the Kōno clan's unofficial alliance with local pirates and the castle's defensive position.

Okou is a castle town located in a a key strategic location in the southern part of Shikoku, that has been serving as the ancestral seat of the Chōsokabe clan since the Kamakura period. Okou recently played a crucial role in the consolidation of power by Chōsokabe Motochika.

Amagiri is a fortified town on top of the namesake Mountain, built by the Kagawa Clan as its seat in the Northern part of Shikoku. Thanks to its strategically fortified location and access to the Inland Sea coast, Amagiri is an important centre for controlling the surrounding territory and trade routes.

Ushiki is a castle town in eastern Kyushu built by the Daimyo Ōtomo Sōrin as the main base for his expanding domain. Located on what is virtually an island connected to the rest of Kyushu only during low tides, Ushiki dominates the eponymous bay.

The castle town of Kurokawa was built by the Ashina clan as its seat in the southernmost part of Ōu region, an isolated area that ensured that Kurokawa could grow while avoiding the worst of the conflicts between neighbouring lords.

Built during the Kamakura period, the castle town of Yonezawa has served as the seat of the Date clan since they drove out the previous lords and from here they plan the domination of neighbouring domains.

Yamagata has been the seat of the Mogami since before they adopted this name, its location marked by the many mountains and rivers that shield it and at the same time make it an important connection centre for the surrounding regions.

Ishinomaki is a bustling coastal town in the southern part of the Ōu region that has grown as an important port for trade and fishing as Matsushima Bay provides natural protection and the Kitakami River serves as a vital route for transporting goods inland. Although its strategic location has ensured its prosperity, it also makes it an important military target for the plans of expansion of the local clans.

Sakata is a a key port in the northern part of the Tōhoku region, the castle town has grown into a vital hub for trade, particularly due to its access to the Sea of Japan and its proximity to the rich agricultural lands of the surrounding region.

Situated along the windswept coastline of northern Honshu, Tzuchizaki‑Minato has long served as a crucial point for maritime trade and the transport of goods between the main islands and the northern provinces.
Located along a key mountain pass, Sannohoe is a fortified town that serves as a military outpost, guarding vital routes for trade and troop movements on the borders of competing powers.

Located in the northernmost reaches of Honshu, Tosaminato serves as a key trade hub with the Ainu people of Hokkaido although the harsh winters and isolation make it difficult to defend, leaving it vulnerable to raids. Once a thriving port and administrative center of the Andō clan, Tosaminato has declined following the clan’s expulsion.
This is the retirement retreat location.
The Hokkoku Bune is a very large, slow moving transport vessel, designed to move an enourmous amount of cargo, but is vulnerable in combat.
The Kobaya Bune is a small, fast moving ship designed for skirmishing and reconnaissance.
The Seki Bune is a medium sized troop transport vessel, designed for transporting troops across the seas. It can hold it's own in a direct naval engagement.
Siege Braziers and additional material allow archers to light their arrows on fire
Naval Cannons are rare, and take time to set up, but are devistating to fortifications
Tate shields provide defenses for ranged units
Ammunition Cache provides a resuply point for archers and gunners
Rice is taken and brewed into sake. Few things keeps the common folk and troops as happy as sake.
We ferment soybeans into miso and soy sauce. Everyone loves soy!
Perilla or whale oil are converted into smooth oil in the press. Oil is used to light lamps, for soap, and for many other purposes.
We work wood and ramie into fine bows and arrows.
We make candles out of whale fat or lacquer.
We specialize in the creation of tools, used in other professions.
Armorsmithies are fundamental for militaries, producing protective armor for troops.
Weaponsmithies are fundamental for militaries, producing melee weaponry for troops.
Rare precious metals are turned into valuable jewelery by jewelers. Jewelery is the finest of all trade goods.
We form the raw fibers of ramie into a usable cloth.
We form the raw fibers of cotton into a usable cloth.
We weave raw silk into usable material to create the most luxurious clothing.
We create Tanegashima guns using iron, wood, and sulfur.

One of the dominant clans in Kyushu, the Otomo lay claim to swathes of the hilly eastern side of the island. Flourishing port cities along the coast have introduced Christianity and trade to the Otomo lands. Thanks to this cooperation with Europe, the Otomo clan have gained an upper hand in Japan's technological arms race by bolstering their ranks with imported matchlock weapons. With land reaching from Bungo in the south to Hakata in the north the realm of the Otomo is not without contention. The Mori clan have come from Honshu taking Moji castle and now threatening Otomo control of the vital port city of Hakata. With a Mori foothold now in Kyushu and with Ryūzōji power rising in the west, the Otomo must rally under clan daimyo Otomo Sorin or risk losing vital land and ports.
The Yamakuguri-shu are a mercenary company of mountain priests originating from Mount Kinpo. They act as shinobi to investigate and spy on enemies, and are a competent fighting force.
The Shiwaku-shu are a mercenary company consisting of mainly transport vessels. They have served many clans in their logistical efforts, but are not known for their military prowess.

The Tango-Kaizoku are a mercenary company of pirates with a stronghold in the Tango province. They are one of the biggest pirate factions and boast a fleet of hundreds of ships. Their numbers are something to be feared.

The Saika-shu are a mercenary company consisting of teppo troops and jizamurai. They were quick to adopt the use of matchlocks and prove their effectiveness. Now they are known for their accurate and deadly use of guns.

The Hakusan-shuto are a mercenary company of warrior monks. They worked closely with the Asakura clan and much of their strength is thanks to them. They come from the Hakusan Heisenji temple, and are a formidable group of warriors.

The Katsurayama-shu are a mercenary company of former samurai turned monk. They are based on the mountains of Togakushi and Iizuna. They are known for their knowledge of mountain terrain and gun usage.
The Suruga-shu are a mercenary company focused on naval warfare. They are known for logisitcal support in the southern Chubu region.
The Kazama-shu are a mercenary company focused on espionage and reconnaissance. They have a bad reputation due to their looting and theft, but are effective in combat.
The Kurohabaki-shu are a mercenary company focused on espionage and sabotage. They are known for their unconvential and disruptive tactics.

Saikaidō, meaning 'West Sea Circuit', is the westernmost region of Japan, comprising the island of Kyushu. Far from the power struggles for control of the shogunate in the capital and closer to the Asian mainland, the region has grown into a maritime and trade center, with goods and new ideas being brought by Chinese and Korean traders and most recently by newly come nanban foreigners. Although the Saikai people have a long tradition of sea commerce with other countries, they are no strangers to warfare either, as daimyo battle for control of the islands while swarms of pirates harass the profitable trade routes for plunder.

The Saikai people hail from the westernmost region of Japan, encompassing the island of Kyushu, which is closer to the Asian mainland than the shogunal capital and its power struggles. Thanks to their unique position, the Saikai have grown into expert seafarers and merchants with longstanding trade relations with China and Korea, and most recently with the newly come nanban foreigners who provide the Saikai with easier access to Western firearms. Yet not all the Saikai embrace trade as their call, as many take to the sea as pirates to plunder the rich trade routes, while the local lords battle to preserve their autonomy from any central authority.

The Nankai people dwell on the mountainous islands of Awaji and Shikoku. Despite being skilled seafarers, the Nankai have developed a strong identity and deep attachment to their homeland which they cultivate with dedication and reverence yielding much more than the average harvest. On the other hand, Nankai have grown isolated and suspicious of the denizens of the other regions, leading them to focus more on the defense of their hometowns and their people.

The San'yo people are native to the westernmost region of Honshu, whose challenging and mountainous terrain has driven them towards the coast, making the San'yo expert sailors who navigate the seas of Japan with ease and great agility. Thanks to their renowned maritime prowess, the San'yo home region has turned into a major trade hub, with large port cities such as Onomichi flourishing and yielding large tax revenues.

The Kinki people reside in the central part of Honshu representing the cultural, economic, and political heart of Japan. The direct heirs of the potentates who once ruled over the entire country, the Kinki benefit from the power structures left behind by their forebears, making it easier for them to consolidate their control over the different regions of Japan. The poetic tradition that flourished around Kyoto contributes to a growing renown of victorious warlords who emulate the deeds of legendary heroes. Nevertheless, years of armed clashes and political scheming for power make it consistently difficult for the Kinki lords to put aside their differences and unite against a common enemy.

The Hokuriku people reside in the strategically vital mountain passes and fertile coastal plains of northern Honshu that have long been targeted by neighboring warlords to control their key position. Over time, the Hokuriku have developed exceptional skills in defending their territory, often bolstering their ranks with warrior monks thanks to their proximity to powerful Buddhist temples. However, the internal stability of the region is increasingly threatened by the rise of the Jōdo Shinshū Buddhist sect that is gaining popularity among the Hokuriku and the Ikko Ikki rebels, whose fervor and uprisings challenge the traditional power structures.

The people of Tosan reside in a region characterized by rugged mountainous terrain, which almost completely cuts off the local communities from the rest of the country, who have long become self-sufficient in order to survive the harsh climate. The Tosan have mastered the adverse terrain they traverse with surprising ease to reach timber and mineral deposits, and have developed a subsistence economy around the villages in the fertile valleys that allows them to sustain minimal growth and some excellences such as the renowned horses of the Kiso Valley.

The Tokai people hail from the fertile lowlands and coastlines of central-southern Honshu, which serves as the ideal boundary between west and east of the country. This has led the Tokai to develop a highly rural society based around sprawling village communities, while urban centers are limited to relatively small settlements unable to compete with the thriving towns of the rest of Japan. Despite the seemingly idyllic setting, such a strategic position makes the region a target for ambitious neighbours, and the Tokai have learnt the imperative of remaining united in arms in the face of external threats much longer than most normally would.

The people of Kanto, the spiritual homeland of the samurai class, live in a predominantly flat region that is perfect for extensive agriculture and the breeding of its renowned battle steeds, which yield abundant harvests and allow Kanto to field and maintain cavalry forces more easily. Imbued with the secular martial tradition in which they have their roots, the lords of Kanto can more easily raise large armies to face their enemies, but their great emphasis on military preparedness makes it more expensive to pay the wages of their soldiers.

The Ou people, native to the harsh, snow-covered lands of northern Honshu, have adapted to their frosty environment with remarkable resilience. Skilled in traversing snowy terrain, the Ou navigate blizzards and icy conditions with ease, moving swiftly where others would struggle, and are accustomed to strict rationing when foraging is not possible, allowing them to endure longer in the snowy wastelands. However, the relentless winters take their toll, and their remote and rugged villages struggle to grow as rapidly as those in more temperate regions, limiting their expansion and development.

Hello {PLAYER.NAME}. I've received word about your victory in the local tournament. I wish to personally offer you congratulations. Well done. Many skilled fighters enter these tournaments and you came out on top. I hope to see your skills develop even further. Perhaps one day you may join my retinue personally. That is all, dismissed.

Well met, I am Kaito. My crew and I sail these waters convincing merchants to part with their cargo, and I will leave it at that. Recently, a ship loaded with exotic wares crossed our path and now we have more cargo than we can take into market without drawing attention. So how about you buy a crate from us right now? We can make a wager of it!
I’ve got more cargo, want to try another one?

For {GOLD_COST} Gold you can take one of these crates off my hands and keep whatever is inside. It’s only fair I give you an equal chance, so I haven’t looked inside. It could be something I regret giving up or something I’ll be glad I parted with. Only one way to find out!{newline}What do you say?
Your loss, I'll be around if you change your mind.
I think I'm done for now.

Our gold reserves are running low, and I’m worried we may not be able to soon pay our men. You should consider building workshops or setting up trade caravans to increase income. If you have any spare equipment we can sell, that can help in the short run. We could also pillage for a profit, but that’s not my favorite option.
We’re running low on food. We need a large supply to effectively launch any kind of campaign. Make sure we stock up on supplies soon.

I’m concerned for the morale of the men. Lately it has been quite tough for us, and I’ve overheard talk of desertion. You should consider raising morale by acquiring more types of food, or through other means.
We could use some more horses for the men to ride while we travel. It is much faster than walking and will increase our speed considerably.
We cannot carry all our goods. You should buy more pack animals or lighten our load. It will make it difficult to travel effectively without doing so.
I have no concerns. All the army's needs are accounted for.
You have room for more companions. You should consider hiring more, as they could be helpful in accomplishing your goals.
You can assemble more parties from your companions. They could add more manpower to our cause.
You should focus on increasing your renown, so your deeds may be known to all.
No, I have no advice to offer at this time.
Your men pull you from the battlefield, forced to leave behind the valuable loot.
The scavengers pry through the remaining loot and leave you on the battlefield. You blend in well with the dead soldiers. You awaken after some time to a battlefield that has been picked clean.
Ah, it happens, better luck next time.
That must have been bound for someone important.
I wish I had kept that one!
I wonder how that horse fit in there.
By the way, my prices are going up to {GOLD_COST}{GOLD_ICON}. I'm sure you won't mind.
